connectorUiConfig.title: Exchange Audit Event logs via Legacy Agent
connectorUiConfig.descriptionMarkdown: You can stream all Exchange Audit events from the Windows machines connected to your Microsoft Sentinel workspace using the Windows agent. This connection enables you to view dashboards, create custom alerts, and improve investigation. This is used by ESI Workbooks to provide security insights of your Exchange environment

sampleQueries.query:
Event | where EventLog == 'MSExchange Management'
  | sort by TimeGenerated

dataTypes.name: Event
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
Event | where EventLog == 'MSExchange Management'
  | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time)

value:
Event | where EventLog == 'MSExchange Management'
  | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time) |take 1
        | project IsConnected = true

resourceProvider.permissionsDisplayText: read permissions to shared keys for the workspace are required. [See the documentation to learn more about workspace keys](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/platform/agent-windows#obtain-workspace-id-and-key).

instructionSteps.description: >**NOTE:** This data connector depends on a parser based on a Kusto Function to work as expected. Follow the steps for each Parser to create the Kusto Functions alias : [**ExchangeConfiguration**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ExchangeConfiguration-parser) and [**ESI_ExchConfigAvailableEnvironments**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ESIExchConfigAvailableEnvironments-parser)

instructionSteps.title: 1. Download the Parser files
instructionSteps.description: The latest version of the 2 files [**ExchangeConfiguration.txt**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ExchangeConfiguration-parser) and [**ExchangeEnvironmentList.txt**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ESIExchConfigAvailableEnvironments-parser)

instructionSteps.title: 2. Create Parser **ExchangeConfiguration** function
instructionSteps.description: In 'Logs' explorer of your Microsoft Sentinel's log analytics, copy the content of the file to Log explorer

instructionSteps.title: 3. Save Parser **ExchangeConfiguration** function
instructionSteps.description:
Click on save button.
 Define the parameters as asked on the header of the parser file.
Click save again.

instructionSteps.title: 4. Reproduce the same steps for Parser **ESI_ExchConfigAvailableEnvironments**
instructionSteps.description: Reproduce the step 2 and 3 with the content of 'ExchangeEnvironmentList.txt' file

>**NOTE:** This connector uses Azure Automation to connect to 'Exchange Online' to pull its Security analysis into Microsoft Sentinel. This might result in additional data ingestion costs. Check the [Azure Automation pricing page](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/automation/) for details.

**STEP 2 - Choose ONE from the following two deployment options to deploy the connector and the associated Azure Automation**

>**IMPORTANT:** Before deploying the 'ESI Exchange Online Security Configuration' connector, have the Workspace ID and Workspace Primary Key (can be copied from the following), as well as the Exchange Online tenant name (contoso.onmicrosoft.com), readily available.

**Option 1 - Azure Resource Manager (ARM) Template**

Use this method for automated deployment of the 'ESI Exchange Online Security Configuration' connector.

1. Click the **Deploy to Azure** button below. 

	[![Deploy To Azure](https://aka.ms/deploytoazurebutton)](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-azuredeploy)
2. Select the preferred **Subscription**, **Resource Group** and **Location**. 
3. Enter the **Workspace ID**, **Workspace Key**, **Tenant Name**, 'and/or Other required fields'. 
>4. Mark the checkbox labeled **I agree to the terms and conditions stated above**. 
5. Click **Purchase** to deploy.

**Option 2 - Manual Deployment of Azure Automation**

 Use the following step-by-step instructions to deploy the 'ESI Exchange Online Security Configuration' connector manually with Azure Automation.

instructionSteps.title: A. Create the Azure Automation Account
instructionSteps.description:
1.  From the Azure Portal, navigate to [Azure Automation Account](https://portal.azure.com/#view/HubsExtension/BrowseResource/resourceType/Microsoft.Automation%2FAutomationAccounts).
2. Click **+ Add** at the top.
3. In the **Basics** tab, fill the required fields and give a name to the Azure Automation. 
4. In the **Advanced** and **Networking** and **Tags** Tabs, leave fields as default if you don't need to customize them.
5. 'Make other preferable configuration changes', if needed, then click **Create**.

instructionSteps.title: B. Add Exchange Online Management Module, Microsoft Graph (Authentication, User and Group) Modules
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the Automation Account page, select **Modules**.
2. Click on **Browse gallery** and search the **ExchangeOnlineManagement** module.
3. Select the it and click on **Select**.
4. Choose Version **5.1** on Runtime version field and click on Import button.
Repeat the step for the following modules : 'Microsoft.Graph.Authentication', 'Microsoft.Graph.Users' and 'Microsoft.Graph.Groups. **Attention, you need to wait for Microsoft.Graph.Authentication installation before processing next modules**

instructionSteps.title: C. Download the Runbook Content
instructionSteps.description:
1. Download the latest version of ESI Collector. The latest version can be found here : https://aka.ms/ESI-ExchangeCollector-Script
2. Unzip the file to find the JSON file and the PS1 file for next step.

instructionSteps.title: D. Create Runbook
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the Automation Account page, select the **Runbooks** button.
2. Click on **Create a runbook** and name it like 'ESI-Collector' with a runbook type **PowerShell**, Runtime Version **5.1** and click 'Create'.
2. Import the content of the previous step's PS1 file in the Runbook window.
3. Click on **Publish**

instructionSteps.title: E. Create GlobalConfiguration Variable
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the Automation Account page, select the **Variables** button.
2. Click on **Add a Variable** and name it exaclty 'GlobalConfiguration' with a type **String**.
2. On 'Value' field, copy the content of the previous step's JSON file.
3. Inside the content, replace the values of **WorkspaceID** and **WorkspaceKey**.
4. Click on 'Create' button.

instructionSteps.title: E. Create TenantName Variable
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the Automation Account page, select the **Variables** button.
2. Click on **Add a Variable** and name it exaclty 'TenantName' with a type **String**.
3. On 'Value' field, write the tenant name of your Exchange Online.
4. Click on 'Create' button.

instructionSteps.title: F. Create a Runbook Schedule
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the Automation Account page, select the **Runbook** button and click on your created runbook.
2. Click on **Schedules** and **Add a schedule** button.
3. Click on **Schedule**, **Add a Schedule** and name it. Select **Recurring** value with a reccurence of every 1 day, click 'Create'.
4. Click on 'Configure parameters and run settings'. Leave all empty and click on **OK** and **OK** again.
The RunAs Account of an Azure Automation needs to be created manually. This account is used by the Runbook to access to Exhcange Online Configuration

instructionSteps.title: A. Create the Azure Automation Account
instructionSteps.description:
1. On the created Azure Automation Account, Click on 'Run As accounts'.
2. Click on **Azure Run As Account** and **Create**

instructionSteps.title: B. Exchange Online API delegation
instructionSteps.description:
1. As a **Global Administrator**, go to **App Registrations** and select the application beginning by your Azure Automation account name following by random letters.
2. Go to **API Permissions** and click on **Add a permission**.
3. On 'APIs my organization uses', search for 'Office 365 Exchange Online' app and select it.
4. Click on 'Applications permissions' and check 'Exchange.ManageAsApp' permission. Then click **Add Permissions**.
5. To grant permission, click on **Grant admin consent for contoso**.

instructionSteps.title: C. Exchange Online Role Assignment
instructionSteps.description:
1. As a **Global Administrator**, go to **Roles and Administrators**.
2. Select **Global Readers** role and click to 'Add assignments'.
3. Click on 'No member selected' and search your **RunAs account** beginning by the name of your automation account following by random letters. Select it and click on 'Select'.
4. Click **Next** and validate the assignment by clicking **Assign**.

instructionSteps.title: 3. Create RunAs Account on Azure Automation

instructionSteps.description: To be able to retrieve User information and memberlist of admin groups, the automation account need multiple permission

parameters.title: Assign Microsoft Graph Users/Groups Read permission

instructionSteps.title: A. Microsoft Graph API Permission
instructionSteps.description:
1. As a **Global Administrator**, go to **App Registrations** and select the application nammed as your Azure Automation account name **without** following by random letters.
2. Go to **API Permissions** and click on **Add a permission**.
3. Select 'Microsoft Graph' application.
4. Click on 'Applications permissions' and check 'Group.Read.all' and 'User.Read.All' permissions. Then click **Add Permissions**.
5. To grant permission, click on **Grant admin consent for contoso**.

instructionSteps.title: 4. Assign Microsoft Graph Permission

This is the script that will collect Exchange Information to push content in Microsoft Sentinel.

instructionSteps.title: Download the latest version of ESI Collector
instructionSteps.description: The latest version can be found here : https://aka.ms/ESI-ExchangeCollector-Script

instructionSteps.title: Copy the script folder
instructionSteps.description: Copy the script folder on a server where Exchange PowerShell Cmdlets are present.

instructionSteps.title: Unlock the PS1 Script
instructionSteps.description:
Click right on the PS1 Script and Properties.
 If the script is marked as locked, onlock it.

instructionSteps.title: Configure Network Access
instructionSteps.description: Ensure that the script can contact Azure Analytics (*.ods.opinsights.azure.com).

instructionSteps.title: 1. Install the ESI Collector Script on a server with Exchange Admin PowerShell console

instructionSteps.description:
Launch the 'setup.ps1' script to configure the collector.
 Fill the Log Analytics (Sentinel) Workspace information.
 Fill the Environment name or leave empty.
instructionSteps.title: 2. Configure the ESI Collector Script

instructionSteps.description:
The script needs to be scheduled to send Exchange configuration to Sentinel.
 We recommend to schedule the script once a day.
 The account used to launch the Script needs the be Exchange Organization Administrator
instructionSteps.title: 3. Schedule the ESI Collector Script

connectorUiConfig.title: Exchange Security Insights On-Premise Collector
connectorUiConfig.descriptionMarkdown: Connector used to push Exchange On-Premises Security configuration for Microsoft Sentinel Analysis

dataTypes.name: ESIExchangeConfig_CL
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
ESIExchangeConfig_CL
            | summarize Time = max(EntryDate_s) by GenerationInstanceID_g, ESIEnvironment_s
            | where isnotempty(Time)

value:
ESIExchangeConfig_CL
            | summarize LastLogReceived = max(EntryDate_s) by GenerationInstanceID_g, ESIEnvironment_s
 |take 1
  | project IsConnected = true

sampleQueries.description: View how many Configuration entries exist on the table
sampleQueries.query: ESIExchangeConfig_CL | summarize by GenerationInstanceID_g, EntryDate_s, ESIEnvironment_s

resourceProvider.permissionsDisplayText: read and write permissions are required.

read permissions to shared keys for the workspace are required. [See the documentation to learn more about workspace keys](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/platform/agent-windows#obtain-workspace-id-and-key).

customs.name: Service Account with Exchange Organization Managemend role
customs.description: The service Account that launch the script as scheduled task needs to be Organization Management to be able to retrieve all the needed security Information.

instructionSteps.description: >**NOTE:** This data connector depends on a parser based on a Kusto Function to work as expected. Follow the steps for each Parser to create the Kusto Functions alias : [**ExchangeConfiguration**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ExchangeConfiguration-parser) and [**ESI_ExchConfigAvailableEnvironments**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ESIExchConfigAvailableEnvironments-parser)

instructionSteps.title: 1. Download the Parser files
instructionSteps.description: The latest version of the 2 files [**ExchangeConfiguration.txt**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ExchangeConfiguration-parser) and [**ExchangeEnvironmentList.txt**](https://aka.ms/sentinel-ESI-ExchangeCollector-ESIExchConfigAvailableEnvironments-parser)

instructionSteps.title: 2. Create Parser **ExchangeConfiguration** function
instructionSteps.description: In 'Logs' explorer of your Microsoft Sentinel's log analytics, copy the content of the file to Log explorer

instructionSteps.title: 3. Save Parser **ExchangeConfiguration** function
instructionSteps.description:
Click on save button.
 Define the parameters as asked on the header of the parser file.
Click save again.

instructionSteps.title: 4. Reproduce the same steps for Parser **ESI_ExchConfigAvailableEnvironments**
instructionSteps.description: Reproduce the step 2 and 3 with the content of 'ExchangeEnvironmentList.txt' file
This is the script that will collect Exchange Information to push content in Microsoft Sentinel.

instructionSteps.title: Download the latest version of ESI Collector
instructionSteps.description: The latest version can be found here : https://aka.ms/ESI-ExchangeCollector-Script

instructionSteps.title: Copy the script folder
instructionSteps.description: Copy the script folder on a server where Exchange PowerShell Cmdlets are present.

instructionSteps.title: Unlock the PS1 Script
instructionSteps.description:
Click right on the PS1 Script and Properties.
 If the script is marked as locked, onlock it.

instructionSteps.title: Configure Network Access
instructionSteps.description: Ensure that the script can contact Azure Analytics (*.ods.opinsights.azure.com).

instructionSteps.title: 1. Install the ESI Collector Script on a server with Exchange Admin PowerShell console

 Fill the Environment name or leave empty.

ExchangeAdminAuditLogs Data Parser with template version 2.0.0
ExchangeConfiguration Data Parser with template
ExchangeConfiguration Data Parser with template version 2.0.0

properties.query:
let _SpecificSectionList = split(SpecificSectionList,',');
let _configurationDate = iff(isnull(SpecificConfigurationDate) or isempty(SpecificConfigurationDate),"lastdate",tostring(SpecificConfigurationDate));
let _configurationEnv = split(iff(isnull(SpecificConfigurationEnv) or isempty(SpecificConfigurationEnv) or tolower(SpecificConfigurationEnv) == "all","All",tostring(SpecificConfigurationEnv)),',');
let _target = iff(isnull(Target) or isempty(Target),"On-Premises",Target);
let _targetDate = iff(_configurationDate == "lastdate", ago(7d), iif(_configurationDate == "alllife",ago(1080d),todatetime(_configurationDate)));
let baseRequest = materialize (union isfuzzy=true withsource=TableName ESIAPIExchange*,ESIExchange* 
    | where TimeGenerated > _targetDate
    | extend Source = iff (TableName contains "Online", "Online", "On-Premises")
    | where _target == 'All' or Source == _target
    | extend ScopedEnvironment = iff(_configurationEnv contains "All", "All",ESIEnvironment_s) 
    | where ScopedEnvironment in (_configurationEnv)
    | extend EntryDate = todatetime(EntryDate_s)
    | project-away EntryDate_s);
let findConfigDate = baseRequest
    | extend Env =strcat(Source, "_",ESIEnvironment_s)
    | summarize count() by GenerationInstanceID_g,Env,EntryDate
    | extend distance = iff(_configurationDate == "lastdate" or _configurationDate == "alllife", now() - EntryDate, (EntryDate - todatetime(_configurationDate)))
    | top-nested of Env by Ignore0=max(1), 
        top-nested 1 of distance by Ignore1 = min(distance) asc nulls last, 
        top-nested of GenerationInstanceID_g by Ignore2=max(2) 
    | project GenerationInstanceID_g;
let ParseExchangeConfig = () { baseRequest 
 | join kind=leftsemi (findConfigDate) on $left.GenerationInstanceID_g == $right.GenerationInstanceID_g
 | where isempty(_SpecificSectionList[0]) or Section_s in (_SpecificSectionList)
 | extend TimeGenerated = EntryDate
 | extend Identity = Identity_Name_s
 | extend CmdletResultValue = parse_json(rawData_s)
 | project-rename ConfigurationInstanceID = GenerationInstanceID_g, ESIEnvironment = ESIEnvironment_s, Section = Section_s, PSCmdlet = PSCmdL_s, CmdletResultType = ExecutionResult_s, WhenChanged = WhenChanged_t, WhenCreated = WhenCreated_t, Name = Name_s
 | project-away TenantId,SourceSystem,Type,EntryDate
};
ParseExchangeConfig

metadata.description: This Workbook, dedicated to Exchange Online environments is built to have a simple view of non-standard RBAC delegations on an Exchange Online tenant. This Workbook allow you to go deep dive on custom delegation and roles and also members of each delegation, including the nested level and the group imbrication on your environment.

The goals of this workbook is to show you the current RBAC delegation


This workbook will display :

  - NonStandrd RBAC delegation

  - Exchange default group content

  - Analysis of the actions performed by Organization Management members to remove them from the groups

----

## Tabs

### Current RBAC Delegation

This tab will show all the nonstandard RBAC delegation.

**Most of the time RBAC are done and forgotten... This tab will provide a clear statut of the delegation and help with the remediation.**

By nonstandard, it means that the current delegation are compared to the delegation from Exchange 2019 CU11.

Nonstandard delegation for standard groups like Organization Management will also be displayed.

Detail information for  found will be displayed : Last logon, last password changed...

### Default Group content

This tab will show the number of members for default Exchange groups and their content.

Most of the time, the content of common Exchange groups but Exchange is shipped with many groups that have very high privileges and its interesting to see that they are not empty as expected.



### Least privileges analysis

This tab will analysis for each account found in the Organization Management groups :

  - All the Cmdlets launch by an account for the define time frame
  
  - For each cmdlet the list of role where the cmdlet is present
	- Each role will be displayed with a weight depending on the criticity of the role. Low number : critical role
	- Role that are clearly Organization Management role will be displayed with the number : 1

  - Proposition of custom RBAC delegations dependant of the result of the analysis

"},"name":"text - 0"}]},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"selected","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"start"},"name":"group - 6"},{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"Custom Role details","items":[{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"List of Custom Roles","items":[{"type":1,"content":{"json":"This section shows the Custom management roles that exist in your environnment and the name of the parent's role"},"name":"text - 0"},{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="MRCustom",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "Online")

----

## Tabs

### Current RBAC Delegation

This tab will show all the nonstandard RBAC delegation.

**Most of the time RBAC are done and forgotten... This tab will provide a clear statut of the delegation and help with the remediation.**

By nonstandard, it means that the current delegation are compared to the delegation from Exchange 2019 CU11.

Nonstandard delegation for standard groups like Organization Management will also be displayed.

Detail information for  found will be displayed : Last logon, last password changed...

### Default Group content

This tab will show the number of members for default Exchange groups and their content.

Most of the time, the content of common Exchange groups but Exchange is shipped with many groups that have very high privileges and its interesting to see that they are not empty as expected."},"name":"text - 0"}]},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"selected","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"start"},"name":"group - 6"},{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"Custom Role details","items":[{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"List of Custom Roles","items":[{"type":1,"content":{"json":"This section shows the Custom management roles that exist in your environnment and the name of the parent's role"},"name":"text - 0"},{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="MRCustom",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "On-Premises")

metadata.description: This workbook is dedicated to On-Premises Exchange organizations. It uses the MSExchange Management event logs to give you a simple way to view administrators’ activities in your Exchange environment with Cmdlets usage statistics and multiple pivots to understand who and/or what is affected to modifications on your environment.

Each entry is analyzed regarding the following conditions :

  - Check if the Target Object is a VIP. The VIP list is based on the watchlist "Exchange VIP".

  - Check if the Cdmlet is a Sensitive Cmdlet. The Sensitive Cmdlet list is based on the watchlist "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets". 
   - This list contains the list of Cmdlet that are considered as Sensitive. 
   - Some Cmdlet will be considered as Sensitive only if some specific parameters defined in the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist are used.

Column explainatations : 
  - Caller : Named of the Administrators that used this cmdlet
  - TargetObject : Object modified by the cmdlet
  - IsVIP : If the Target Object part of the "Exchange VIP" watchlist
  - CmdletName : Name of the cmdlet that was used
  - CmdletParameters : Cmdlet parameters used with the command
  - IsSenstiveCmdlet : 
   - true : the Cmdlet is part of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist
   - false : the Cmdlet is not part of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist
  - IsRestrictedCmdLet : This cmdlet is considered as sentisitve only when some specifc parameters are used
  - ExtractedParameters : List of parameters used by the cmdlet
  - IsSenstiveCmdletParameters :
   - true : Sensitive parameters have been used
   - false : Sensitive parameters have not been used
  - RestrictedParameters : List of restricted parameters used
  - IsSensitive :
   - true : This cmdlet is Sensitive because it was part of the list of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist and Sensitive parameters have been used for cmdlet with specifc sensitive parameters 
  - UserOriented : The Sensitive cmdlet used is a user cmdlet and not a general configuration cmdlet. This information is part of the list of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist

Each entry is analyzed regarding the following conditions :

  - Check if the Target Object is a VIP. The VIP list is based on the watchlist "Exchange VIP".

  - Check if the Cdmlet is a Sensitive Cmdlet. The Sensitive Cmdlet list is based on the watchlist "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets". 
   - This list contains the list of Cmdlet that are considered as Sensitive. 
   - Some Cmdlet will be considered as Sensitive only if some specific parameters defined in the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist are used.

Column explainatations : 
  - Caller : Named of the Administrators that used this cmdlet
  - TargetObject : Object modified by the cmdlet
  - IsVIP : If the Target Object part of the "Exchange VIP" watchlist
  - CmdletName : Name of the cmdlet that was used
  - CmdletParameters : Cmdlet parameters used with the command
  - IsSenstiveCmdlet : 
   - true : the Cmdlet is part of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist
   - false : the Cmdlet is not part of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist
  - IsRestrictedCmdLet : This cmdlet is considered as sentisitve only when some specifc parameters are used
  - ExtractedParameters : List of parameters used by the cmdlet
  - IsSenstiveCmdletParameters :
   - true : Sensitive parameters have been used
   - false : Sensitive parameters have not been used
  - RestrictedParameters : List of restricted parameters used
  - IsSensitive :
   - true : This cmdlet is Sensitive because it was part of the list of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist and Sensitive parameters have been used for cmdlet with specifc sensitive parameters 
  - UserOriented : The Sensitive cmdlet used is a user cmdlet and not a general configuration cmdlet. This information is part of the list of the "Monitored Exchange Cmdlets" watchlist

The goals of this workbook is to allow search in the Exchange Admin Audit log.

The source of this workbook is not an export of the Admin Audit log mailbox but an export of the MSExchange Management for each Exchange servers.

If the Admin Audit Log is bypassed, the information won't be displayed in this workbook as there is  no method to track this data.

## Tabs

Let quicly review the content of each tab

### Cmdlets Analysis

This tab will show for the defined time range :
  - A summary of all cmdets used

  - A summary of all cmdlets used by each Account

### Global Admin Audit Log

This tab allow to globally search in the exported Admin Audit log content.

When Sensitive Cmdlets and/or Sensitive parameters are used, specific informations will be displayed.

When VIP user are manipulated, specific informations will be displayed.

For more informations on how to understand each Column, refer to "How to understand the data"


### AdminAuditLog for Org Mgmt

This tab allow to globally search in the exported Admin Audit log content for only account members on the Organization Management groups.

When Sensitive Cmdlets and/or Sensitive parameters are used, specific informations will be displayed.

When VIP user are manipulated, specific informations will be displayed.

For more informations on how to understand each Column, refer to "How to understand the data""},"name":"text - 0"}]},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"selected","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Start"},"name":"group - 5"}],"fromTemplateId":"sentinel-MicrosoftExchangeSearchAdminAuditLog","$schema":"https://github.com/Microsoft/Application-Insights-Workbooks/blob/master/schema/workbook.json"}

It uses the MSExchange Management event logs to give you a simple way to view administrators’ activities in your Exchange environment with Cmdlets usage statistics and multiple pivots to understand who and/or what is affected to modifications on your environment.; dataTypesDependencies=System.Object[]; dataConnectorsDependencies=System.Object[]; previewImagesFileNames=System.Object[]; version=1.0.0; title=Microsoft Exchange Search AdminAuditLog; templateRelativePath=Microsoft Exchange Search AdminAuditLog.json; subtitle=; provider=Microsoft}.description
Microsoft Exchange Security Workbook with template
Microsoft Exchange Security MonitoringWorkbook Workbook with template version 2.0.0

metadata.description: This Workbook is dedicated to On-Premises Exchange organizations. It uses the MSExchange Management event logs and Microsoft Exchange Security configuration collected by data connectors. It helps to track admin actions, especially on VIP Users and/or on Sensitive Cmdlets. This workbook allows also to list Exchange Services changes, local account activities and local logon on Exchange Servers.

properties.description: @{workbookKey=MicrosoftExchangeSecurityMonitoring; logoFileName=Azure_Sentinel.svg; description=This Workbook is dedicated to On-Premises Exchange organizations. It uses the MSExchange Management event logs and Microsoft Exchange Security configuration collected by data connectors. It helps to track admin actions, especially on VIP Users and/or on Sensitive Cmdlets. This workbook allows also to list Exchange Services changes, local account activities and local logon on Exchange Servers.; dataTypesDependencies=System.Object[]; dataConnectorsDependencies=System.Object[]; previewImagesFileNames=System.Object[]; version=1.0.0; title=Microsoft Exchange Security Monitoring; templateRelativePath=Microsoft Exchange Security Monitoring.json; subtitle=; provider=Microsoft}.description
Microsoft Exchange Security Workbook with template
Microsoft Exchange Security Review - OnlineWorkbook Workbook with template version 2.0.0

metadata.description: This Workbook is dedicated to Exchange Online tenants. It displays and highlights current Security configuration on various Exchange components specific to Online including delegations, the transport configuration and the linked security risks, and risky protocols.

properties.serializedData:
{"version":"Notebook/1.0","items":[{"type":1,"content":{"json":"# Microsoft Exchange Security Review Online"},"name":"text - 2"},{"type":9,"content":{"version":"KqlParameterItem/1.0","parameters":[{"id":"9ae328d6-99c8-4c44-8d59-42ca4d999098","version":"KqlParameterItem/1.0","name":"EnvironmentList","label":"Environment","type":2,"isRequired":true,"multiSelect":true,"quote":"'","delimiter":",","query":"ESI_ExchConfigAvailableEnvironments(Target="Online") | where ESIEnvironment != ""","value":["CONTOSO"],"typeSettings":{"limitSelectTo":1,"showDefault":false},"defaultValue":"value::all","queryType":0,"resourceType":"microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces"},{"id":"a88b4e41-eb2f-41bf-92d8-27c83650a4b8","version":"KqlParameterItem/1.0","name":"DateOfConfiguration","label":"Collection time","type":2,"isRequired":true,"query":"let _configurationEnv = split(iff(isnull({EnvironmentList}) or isempty({EnvironmentList}) or tolower({EnvironmentList}) == "all","All",tostring({EnvironmentList})),',');
ESIExchangeOnlineConfig_CL
| extend ScopedEnvironment = iff(_configurationEnv contains "All", "All",ESIEnvironment_s) 
| where ScopedEnvironment in (_configurationEnv)
| extend Collection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd')
| summarize Collection = max(Collection)
| project Collection = "lastdate", Selected = true
| join kind= fullouter  ( ESIExchangeOnlineConfig_CL | extend ScopedEnvironment = iff(_configurationEnv contains "All", "All",ESIEnvironment_s) 
    | where ScopedEnvironment in (_configurationEnv)
    | where TimeGenerated > ago(90d)
    | extend Collection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd')
    | summarize by Collection 
    | join kind= fullouter ( ESIExchangeOnlineConfig_CL | extend ScopedEnvironment = iff(_configurationEnv contains "All", "All",ESIEnvironment_s) 
        | where ScopedEnvironment in (_configurationEnv)
        | where TimeGenerated > ago(90d)
        | extend Collection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd')
        | extend PreciseCollection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm ')
        | summarize by PreciseCollection, Collection 
        | join kind=leftouter (
            ESIExchangeOnlineConfig_CL | extend ScopedEnvironment = iff(_configurationEnv contains "All", "All",ESIEnvironment_s) 
            | where ScopedEnvironment in (_configurationEnv)
            | where TimeGenerated > ago(90d)
            | extend Collection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd')
            | extend PreciseCollection = format_datetime(todatetime(EntryDate_s), 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm')
            | summarize by PreciseCollection, Collection 
            | summarize count() by Collection
        ) on Collection
    ) on Collection
) on Collection

The goal of this workbook is to outline key security configurations of your Exchange on-premises environment.

Most of Exchange organizations have were installed years ago (sometimes more than 10 years). Many configurations have been done and might not have been documented. For most environments, the core commitment was maintaining a high availability of the users’ mailboxes putting aside other consideration (even security considerations). Recommended security practices have also evolved since the first released and a regular review is necessary.

This workbook is designed to show your Exchange organization is configured with a security point of view. Indeed, some configurations easy to display as there are no UI available.

For each configuration, you will find explanations and recommendations when applicable.

- This workbook does not pretend to show you every weak Security configurations, but the most common issues and known to be used by attackers. 
- It will not show you if you have been comprised, but will help you identify unexpected configuration.

----

## Quick reminder of how Exchange works

During Exchange installation two very important groups are created :
- Exchange Trusted Subsystem : Contain all the computer accounts for Exchange Server
- Exchange Windows Permissions : Contain the group Exchange trusted Subsystem

These groups have :
- Very high privileges in ALL AD domains including the root domain
- Right on any Exchange including mailboxes

As each Exchange server computer account is member of Exchange Trusted Subsystem, it means by taking control of the computer account or being System on an Exchange server you will gain access to all the permissions granted to Exchange Trusted Subsystem and Exchange Windows Permissions.

To protect AD and Exchange, it is very important to ensure the following:
- There is a very limited number of persons that are local Administrator on Exchange server
- To protect user right like : Act part of the operating System, Debug

Every service account or application that have high privileges on Exchange need to be considered as sensitive

** 💡 Exchange servers need to be considered as very sensitive servers**

-----


## Tabs

### Mailbox Access

This tab will show you several top sensitive delegations that allow an account to access, modify, act as another user, search, export the content of a mailbox.

### Exchange & AD Groups

This tab will show you the members of Exchange groups and Sensitive AD groups.

### Local Administrators

This tab will show you the non standard content of the local Administrators group. Remember that a member of the local Administrators group can take control of the computer account of the server and then it will have all the permissions associated with Exchange Trusted Subsytem and Exchange Windows Permissions

The information is displayed with different views : 
- List of nonstandard users
- Number of servers with a nonstandard a user
- Nonstandard groups content
- For each user important information are displayed like last logon, last password set, enabled

### Exchange Security configuration

This tab will show you some important configuration for your Exchange Organization
- Status of Admin Audit Log configuration
- Status of POP and IMAP configuration : especially, is Plaintext Authentication configured ?
- Nonstandard permissions on the Exchange container in the Configuration Partition

### Transport Configuration

This tab will show you the configuration of the main Transport components
- Receive Connectors configured with Anonymous and/or Open Relay
- Remote Domain Autoforward configuration
- Transport Rules configured with BlindCopyTo, SendTo, RedirectTo
- Journal Rule and Journal Recipient configurations
- Accepted Domains with *

- Ensure that no service account are a member of the high privilege groups. Use RBAC to delegate the exact required permissions.
- Limit the usage of nested group for administration.
- Ensure that accounts are given only the required pernissions to execute their tasks.
- Use just in time administration principle by adding users in a group only when they need the permissions, then remove them when their operation is over.
- Limit the number of Organization management members. When you review the Admin Audit logs you might see that the administrators rarely needed Organization Management privileges.
- Monitor the content of the following groups:
  - TenantAdmins_-xxx (Membership in this role group is synchronized across services and managed centrally)
  - Organization Management
  - ExchangeServiceAdmins_-xxx (Membership in this role group is synchronized across services and managed centrally)
  - Recipient Management (Member of this group have at least the following rights : set-mailbox, Add-MailboxPermission)
  - Discovery Management
  - Hygiene Management
  - Security Administrator (Membership in this role group is synchronized across services and managed centrally)
  - xxx High privilege group (not an exhaustive list)
  - Compliance Management
  - All RBAC groups that have high roles delegation
  - All nested groups in high privileges groups
  - Note that this is not a complete list. The content of all the groups that have high privileges should be monitored.
- Each time a new RBAC group is created, decide if the content of this groups should be monitored
- Periodically review the members of the groups","style":"info"},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"Help","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Yes"},"name":"text - 0"},{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"Number of  direct members per group with RecipientType User","items":[{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="RoleGroupMember",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "Online")

When the Default Remote domain is set to * and has the AutoForwardEnabled set True, any user can configure an Outlook rule to automatically forward all emails to any SMTP domain domains outside the organization. This is a high risk configuration as it might allow accounts to leak information. 

Also, when setting AutoForwardEnabled to a specific domain, it is strongly recommended enable TLS encryption.","style":"info"},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"Help","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Yes"},"name":"AutoForwardHelp"},{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="RemoteDomain",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "Online")

This workbook helps also to understand the transport configuration and the linked security risks.

The goal of this workbook is to outline key security configurations of your Exchange on-premises environment.

Most of Exchange organizations have were installed years ago (sometimes more than 10 years). Many configurations have been done and might not have been documented. For most environments, the core commitment was maintaining a high availability of the users’ mailboxes putting aside other consideration (even security considerations). Recommended security practices have also evolved since the first released and a regular review is necessary.

This workbook is designed to show your Exchange organization is configured with a security point of view. Indeed, some configurations easy to display as there are no UI available.

For each configuration, you will find explanations and recommendations when applicable.

- This workbook does not pretend to show you every weak Security configurations, but the most common issues and known to be used by attackers. 
- It will not show you if you have been comprised, but will help you identify unexpected configuration.

----

## Quick reminder of how Exchange works

During Exchange installation two very important groups are created :
- Exchange Trusted Subsystem : Contain all the computer accounts for Exchange Server
- Exchange Windows Permissions : Contain the group Exchange trusted Subsystem

These groups have :
- Very high privileges in ALL AD domains including the root domain
- Right on any Exchange including mailboxes

As each Exchange server computer account is member of Exchange Trusted Subsystem, it means by taking control of the computer account or being System on an Exchange server you will gain access to all the permissions granted to Exchange Trusted Subsystem and Exchange Windows Permissions.

To protect AD and Exchange, it is very important to ensure the following:
- There is a very limited number of persons that are local Administrator on Exchange server
- To protect user right like : Act part of the operating System, Debug

Every service account or application that have high privileges on Exchange need to be considered as sensitive

** 💡 Exchange servers need to be considered as very sensitive servers**

-----


## Tabs

### Mailbox Access

This tab will show you several top sensitive delegations that allow an account to access, modify, act as another user, search, export the content of a mailbox.

### Exchange & AD Groups

This tab will show you the members of Exchange groups and Sensitive AD groups.

### Local Administrators

This tab will show you the non standard content of the local Administrators group. Remember that a member of the local Administrators group can take control of the computer account of the server and then it will have all the permissions associated with Exchange Trusted Subsytem and Exchange Windows Permissions

The information is displayed with different views : 
- List of nonstandard users
- Number of servers with a nonstandard a user
- Nonstandard groups content
- For each user important information are displayed like last logon, last password set, enabled

### Exchange Security configuration

This tab will show you some important configuration for your Exchange Organization
- Status of Admin Audit Log configuration
- Status of POP and IMAP configuration : especially, is Plaintext Authentication configured ?
- Nonstandard permissions on the Exchange container in the Configuration Partition

### Transport Configuration

This tab will show you the configuration of the main Transport components
- Receive Connectors configured with Anonymous and/or Open Relay
- Remote Domain Autoforward configuration
- Transport Rules configured with BlindCopyTo, SendTo, RedirectTo
- Journal Rule and Journal Recipient configurations
- Accepted Domains with *

- Unexpected behaviors
- Who did a modification
- Real actions performed by an account (the output could be used with to identify the necessary privileges)

ℹ️ Recommendations
- Ensure that Admin Audit Log is not disabled
- Ensure that critical Cmdlets have not been excluded
- Review the retention configuration for the Admin Audit Log content","style":"info"},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"Help","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Yes"},"name":"AdminAuditHelp"},{"type":1,"content":{"json":"Here the main settings for the Admin Audit Log. let AAL = (ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="AdminAuditLog",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "On-Premises")
| extend AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets = CmdletResultValue.AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets
| project AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets);

ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="AdminAuditLog",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "On-Premises")
| project CmdletResultValue

| extend AdminAuditLogAgeLimit = tostring(CmdletResultValue.AdminAuditLogAgeLimit)

| extend AdminAuditLogAgeLimit =substring(AdminAuditLogAgeLimit,0,indexof(AdminAuditLogAgeLimit, ','))
| extend AdminAuditLogAgeLimit = iff(toint(AdminAuditLogAgeLimit) == 0,strcat("❌ No AdminAuditlog recorded ",AdminAuditLogAgeLimit), iff(toint(AdminAuditLogAgeLimit) <=30,strcat("⚠️ Value to low except if exported ",AdminAuditLogAgeLimit), strcat("✅",AdminAuditLogAgeLimit)))
| extend AdminAuditLogCmdlets = tostring(CmdletResultValue.AdminAuditLogCmdlets)

| extend AdminAuditLogCmdlets = substring(AdminAuditLogCmdlets,0,indexof(AdminAuditLogCmdlets, '"]') )
| extend AdminAuditLogCmdlets = replace_string(AdminAuditLogCmdlets,'"',"")
| extend Comment_AdminAuditLogCmdlets = iff( AdminAuditLogCmdlets == "*","✅ Default configuration","❌ Only AdminAuditLogCmdlets will be logged")
| extend AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets = tostring(CmdletResultValue.AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets)
| extend AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets = substring(AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets,2)
| extend AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets = substring(AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets,0,indexof(AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets, ']'))

| project-away CmdletResultValue
| extend Comment_AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlet = case(  isnotempty( SentsitivecmdletTrack ),"❌ Some excluded CmdLets are part of Sensitive Cmdlets",AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets <>"","⚠️ Some Cmdlets are excluded ","✅ No Excluded CmdLet")","size":3,"showAnalytics":true,"queryType":0,"resourceType":"microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces"},"name":"query - 1","styleSettings":{"showBorder":true}}]},"name":"group - 0Admin Audit Log configuration"},{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"POP authentication configuration"},"name":"POP authentication configuration"},{"type":1,"content":{"json":"
If the POP Service is started, the LoginType should not set to Plaintext. This means that the password will be sent in clear on the network. As POP is enabled by default on all the mailboxes, this represents a high security risk.

POP Authentication
- **PlainText** TLS encryption is not required on port 110.  Usernames and passwords are sent unencrypted unless the underlying connection is encrypted by using TLS or SSL.
- **PlainTextAuthentication** TLS encryption is not required on port 110. However, Basic authentication is permitted only on a port that uses TLS or SSL encryption.
- **SecureLogin** Connection on port 110  must use TLS encryption before authenticating.

ℹ️ Recommendations
Disable POP on all mailboxes except those who need to actually use this protocol.
Set the authentication to SecureLogin or at least to PlainTextAuthentication and configure the application.

If the application is not able to perform this type of authentication:
- Ensure that POP is disabled on all the mailboxes except those who really need it 
- Monitor the POP connections
- Change the password of the application on a regular basis

Documentation
Configuring Authentication for POP3 and IMAP4 : https://technet.microsoft.com/library/aa997188(v=exchg.141).aspx

Set-PopSettings
https://technet.microsoft.com/library/aa997154(v=exchg.160).aspx


In order to track mailboxes that are currently using POP
- Enable POP logging
- Set-PopSettings -Server SRV1  -ProtocolLogEnabled verbose
- Several weeks later, analyze the log content
- Default location :    - Get-PopSettings -server SRV1 | fl server,*log*
- Check for connection and authentication
","style":"info"},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"Help","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Yes"},"name":"PopServiceHelp"},{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="PopSettings",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "On-Premises")

This means that the passwords will be sent in clear over the network. As IMAP is enabled by default on all the mailboxes, this is a high security risk.

IMAP Authentication
- **PlainText** TLS encryption is not required on port 110.  User name and password are sent unencrypted unless the underlying connection is encrypted by using TLS or SSL.
- **PlainTextAuthentication** TLS encryption is not required on port 143. However, Basic authentication is permitted only on a port that uses TLS or SSL encryption.
- **SecureLogin** Connection on port 143 must use TLS encryption before authenticating.

ℹ️ Recommendations 
Disable IMAP on all mailboxes except those which needs to use this protocol. Set the authentication to SecureLogin or at least to PlainTextAuthentication and configure the application accordingly.

If the application is not able to perform this type of authentication:
- Ensure that IMAP is disable on all the mailboxes except those who really need it 
- Monitor the connection
- Regularly, change the password of the application


Recommended Reading
Configuring Authentication for IMAP3 and IMAP4 : https://technet.microsoft.com/library/aa997188(v=exchg.141).aspx
Set-ImapSettings : 
https://technet.microsoft.com/library/aa998252(v=exchg.160).aspx



In order to track mailboxes that are currently using IMAP
- Enable IMAP logging
- Set-IMAPSettings -Server SRV1  -ProtocolLogEnabled verbose
- Several weeks later, analyze the log content
- Default location :  Get-IMAPSettings -server SRV1 | fl server,*log*
- Check for connection and authentication

- Ensure that no service account are a member of the high privilege groups. Use RBAC to delegate the exact required permissions.
- Limit the usage of nested group for administration.
- Ensure that accounts are given only the required pernissions to execute their tasks.
- Use just in time administration principle by adding users in a group only when they need the permissions, then remove them when their operation is over.
- Limit the number of Organization management members. When you review the Admin Audit logs you might see that the administrators rarely needed Organization Management privileges.
- Monitor the content of the following groups:
  - Organization Management
  - Recipient Management (Member of this group have at least the following rights : set-mailbox, Add-MailboxPermission)
  - Discovery Management
  - Server Management
  - Hygiene Management
  - Exchange Servers
  - Exchange Trusted Subsystem  
  - Exchange Windows Permissions
  - xxx High privilege group (not an exhaustive list)
  - All RBAC groups that have high roles delegation
  - All nested groups in high privileges groups
  - Note that this is not a complete list. The content of all the groups that have high privileges should be monitored.
- Each time a new RBAC group is created, decide if the content of this groups should be monitored
- Periodically review the members of the groups","style":"info"},"conditionalVisibility":{"parameterName":"Help","comparison":"isEqualTo","value":"Yes"},"name":"text - 0"},{"type":12,"content":{"version":"NotebookGroup/1.0","groupType":"editable","title":"Number of members per group","items":[{"type":3,"content":{"version":"KqlItem/1.0","query":"ExchangeConfiguration(SpecificSectionList="ExGroup",SpecificConfigurationDate="{DateOfConfiguration:value}",SpecificConfigurationEnv={EnvironmentList},Target = "On-Premises")

properties.description: CriticalCmdletsUsageDetection_AnalyticalRules Analytics Rule with template version 2.0.0
Alert if an high important Cmdlet is executed on a VIP Mailbox as those Cmdlets can be used for data exfiltration or mailbox access.
properties.query:
ExchangeAdminAuditLogs
| where ingestion_time() > ago(30m)
| where IsSensitive == true
| where UserOriented =~ 'Yes'
| where IsVIP == true

properties.description: Microsoft Exchange Security Analytics Rule 1
Microsoft Exchange Security Analytics Rule 2 with template
properties.displayName: Microsoft Exchange Security Analytics Rule template

properties.description: ServerOrientedWithUserOrientedAdministration_AnalyticalRules Analytics Rule with template version 2.0.0
Detect if a server oriented Cmdlet and a user oriented cmdlet that are monitored are launched by a same user in a same server in a 10 minutes timeframe
properties.displayName: Server Oriented Cmdlet And User Oriented Cmdlet used
properties.query:
let timeframe = 1d;
let spanoftime = 10m;
let threshold = 0;
ExchangeAdminAuditLogs 
  | where TimeGenerated > ago(2 * timeframe)
  | where isempty(UserOriented)
  | project serverExecutedTime = TimeGenerated,
    ServerCmdlet = CmdletName,
    ServerCmdletParams = CmdletParameters,
    Computer,
    Caller,
    ServerCmdletTargetObject = TargetObject
  | join kind= inner (
      ExchangeAdminAuditLogs
      | where TimeGenerated > ago(timeframe)
      | where UserOriented =~ 'Yes'
      | lookup kind=leftouter _GetWatchlist('ExchangeVIP') on $left.TargetObject == $right.canonicalName
      | project userExecutedTime = TimeGenerated,
        UserCmdlet = CmdletName,
        UserCmdletParams = CmdletParameters,
        Computer,
        Caller,
        UserCmdletTargetObject = TargetObject,
        userPrincipalName,
        objectGUID,
        sAMAccountName,
        IsVIP)
    on Computer, Caller
  | where userExecutedTime - serverExecutedTime < spanoftime
  | extend TimeDelta = userExecutedTime - serverExecutedTime
  | extend TimeDeltaInverse = serverExecutedTime - userExecutedTime
  | where tolong(TimeDelta) >= threshold or tolong(TimeDeltaInverse) >= threshold
